properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and blowing snow on Tuesday. A low pressure system tracking up the American Eastern Seaboard early this week could give more than 15 centimetres of snow on Tuesday. Strong northeasterly winds will also cause blowing snow in the St Lawrence Valley. These conditions could significantly impact rush hour traffic in urban areas. Expect hazardous driving conditions due to low visibility. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T19:02:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-15T03:03:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3618474661.2021

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extremely cold wind chill values below minus 40 will continue overnight. The extreme cold is expected to end on Monday as a warming trend begins across Alberta. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T20:34:16-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A mix of snow and ice pellets is expected on Tuesday. Total snowfall and ice pellet amounts: 15 to 25 cm. Locations: central New Brunswick. Time span: Tuesday morning until Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin spreading across New Brunswick Tuesday morning. A change over to ice pellets is expected over southern New Brunswick late in the morning and will continue to spread towards northern New Brunswick by the afternoon. There is also the likelihood that precipitation will switch to or mix with freezing rain for the evening over southern most regions and persist into Wednesday morning. A freezing rain warning was issued for southwestern New Brunswick and these warnings may be expanded further north and east with subsequent forecasts. ### There may be a significant impact on rush hour traffic in urban areas. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-16T00:44:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-15T08:45:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2280396717.2021

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls off Lake Superior have developed and will continue through tonight. What: Snow squalls. Poor visibility and total snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm are expected. When: Now through 5 a.m. Monday. Where: Areas east of Lake Superior. This includes Highway 17 between Wawa and Odena. Discussion: Lake effect snow squalls off Lake Superior will bring heavy snow and poor visibility along the eastern shore through tonight. Travel will be hazardous as a result. Remember...lake effect snow and snow squalls can cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Actions: ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T13:59:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-15T04:14:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3057231415.2021
Area: Agawa - Lake Superior Park, Searchmont - Montreal River Harbour - Batchawana Bay

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls off Lake Superior have developed and will continue early this morning. What: Snow squalls. Poor visibility and total snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm are expected. When: Now through 6 a.m. Where: Areas east of Lake Superior. This includes Highway 17 near and south of Batchawana Bay. Discussion: Lake effect snow squalls off Lake Superior will bring heavy snow and poor visibility along the eastern shore this morning. Travel will be hazardous as a result. Remember...lake effect snow and snow squalls can cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Actions: ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow Tuesday morning followed by a possible extended period of freezing precipitation Tuesday afternoon and evening. Locations: Prince Edward Island. Time span: Tuesday morning through Tuesday night. Remarks: Periods of snow beginning Tuesday morning then changing to a prolonged period of ice pellets Tuesday afternoon, and to freezing rain Tuesday evening. 10-15 cm of snow and ice pellets is possible before the changeover to freezing rain. Note that this situation may change and it will continue to be closely monitored as it approaches, in case warnings may be required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-16T00:47:46-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow Tuesday with possible extended period of freezing precipitation Tuesday evening. Locations: Iles de la Madeleine Time span: Beginning Tuesday morning through Tuesday night. Remarks: Periods of snow are expected Tuesday morning and continue through the day, changing to a prolonged period of ice pellets and/or freezing rain Tuesday evening and change to rain overnight. Snow amounts could reach or exceed 15 cm before the changeover. Note that as this system is still in the early stages of development, this situation may change and it will continue to be closely monitored as it approaches, in case warnings may be required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall likely Monday night into Tuesday. Light snow is expected to affect the area Monday morning and afternoon with a few centimetres possible. A much more significant area of snow will move into the region Monday evening. The snow will likely fall heavily at times and continue into Tuesday morning. Total amounts of 15 to 25 cm are possible. Snowfall warnings may be issued as this event draws closer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T19:42:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-15T03:43:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4176790779.2021

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. Second winter storm has arrived. On the heels of a snow-producing storm on Saturday, a Pacific frontal system has arrived on the south coast this morning, spreading snow to the Metro Vancouver region. Rain will fall this evening but will become mixed with snow late this evening and overnight. As is often the case, areas inland and those in the path of the Fraser Valley outflow winds particularly can expect snow to continue through Monday. Snowfall amounts will vary due to the timing of the transition and are likely to be much higher over higher terrain as the rain-snow line is expected to fluctuate between sea level and 200 metres tonight and Monday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T23:06:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-15T07:07:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3702779811.2021
Area: Metro Vancouver - North Shore including West Vancouver and North Vancouver, Metro Vancouver - central including the City of Vancouver Burnaby and New Westminster, Metro Vancouver - northeast including Coquitlam and Maple Ridge, Metro Vancouver - southeast including Surrey and Langley, Metro Vancouver - southwest including Richmond and Delta
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Two rounds of snow are expected today into Tuesday morning across portions of southern Ontario. The first one is expected this morning into early this afternoon with 5 cm of snow possible. The snow may become light during the afternoon, however another round of heavier snow will move in this evening and persist into Tuesday morning. An additional 15 to 20 cm is likely. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-16T01:38:58-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter storm today into Tuesday giving 20 to 35 cm of snow. Two rounds of snow are expected with this storm. The first one is expected to begin early this morning with 5 to 10 cm likely by mid afternoon. The snow may diminish in intensity during the afternoon, but another round of heavier snow is expected to move in this evening and persist into Tuesday morning. An additional 10 to 20 cm is likely. Northeast winds gusting near 50 km/h will result in very poor visibility in blowing snow. Even higher amounts may be possible in some locations due to extra moisture coming off Lake Ontario. Locally higher amounts may also occur on the higher elevations of the escarpment. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-16T00:51:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-15T08:52:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3237307416.2021
Area: Dunnville - Caledonia - Haldimand, City of Hamilton, St. Catharines - Grimsby - Northern Niagara Region, Niagara Falls - Welland - Southern Niagara Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Two rounds of snow are expected today into Tuesday morning across portions of southern Ontario. The first one is expected persist into early this afternoon. General amounts of 5 to 10 cm are possible, though snow squall activity is possible near Lake Huron which may result in higher amounts. The snow may diminish during the afternoon, but another round of heavier snow is expected to move in this evening and persist into Tuesday morning. Additional snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are likely. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Prolonged periods of freezing rain on Tuesday. Locations: Nova Scotia Time Span: Tuesday morning through to Tuesday evening. Remarks: Periods of snow and ice pellets across the province tonight and early Tuesday, then changing to a prolonged period of ice pellets then freezing rain, before gradually changing to rain from southwest to northeast across the province on Tuesday. Freezing rain warnings have been issued for all counties except Victoria and Inverness County - Mabou and north, but the warning could be extended to these counties in subsequent forecasts. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. There may be a significant impact on rush hour traffic in urban areas. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A wintry mix of precipitation is expected. Locations: southern Newfoundland and the Avalon Peninsula. Time span: Tuesday afternoon or evening through Wednesday morning. Total snow and ice pellet accumulations: 5 to 10 cm. Maximum wind gusts: southeasterly 50 to 70 km/h, with gusts likely above 100 km/h in the Wreckhouse area on Tuesday night. Winds will shift to southwesterly on Wednesday, gusting between 70 and 90 km/h Remarks: Snow is expected to begin in the southwest on Tuesday afternoon then spread eastward through the evening. Snow will transition through ice pellets and freezing rain to rain Tuesday night. Rain and drizzle will taper off Wednesday morning or afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. AIR QUALITY ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR VANDERHOOF (February 14, 2021 08:00 - Prince George) The Ministry of Environment & Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with the Northern Health Authority has issued an Air Quality Advisory for Prince George and Quesnel due to high concentrations of fine particulate matter. Exposure is particularly a concern for individuals with chronic conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, and diabetes; respiratory infections such as COVID-19, pregnant women, infants, and older adults. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Where appropriate, maintain physical distancing. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Staying indoors helps to reduce particulate matter exposure. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-02-16T01:10:55-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A second winter storm has arrived Sunday morning and will persist into Tuesday giving hazardous winter conditions to the Fraser Valley. Light snow has begun as a Pacific front crosses the South Coast. It will become moderate tonight and intensify on Monday as another system reaches the region. Snow accumulations are expected to reach 10 to 15 cm by Monday afternoon. Periods of freezing rain are likely to occur locally tonight through Monday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected. Total snow and ice pellet accumulations: 15 to 30 cm, with the potential for locally higher amounts. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly 50 to 80 km/h. Locations: western, central, and northeast coast of Newfoundland. Time span: Tuesday afternoon into Wednesday afternoon. Remarks: Snow is forecast to spread across Newfoundland Tuesday afternoon or evening before becoming mixed with or changing to ice pellets in the overnight hours. Snow, ice pellets and potentially freezing rain will eventually taper to flurries by Wednesday afternoon. There is also a chance that the Terra Nova, Clarenville, Bonavista Peninsula areas could see a brief change over to rain on Wednesday. A period of reduced visibility in blowing snow is possible, especially along the northeast coast where winds will be strongest. The details of this system are still subject to change due to some uncertainty in the storms track. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Dangerously cold conditions continue. What: Temperatures of minus 32 to 40; wind chills of minus 40 to 45. Where: Northwestern Ontario. When: Now through Tuesday morning, during the evening, overnight, and early morning hours. Extreme cold is forecast to last into Tuesday, at which time temperatures may moderate somewhat. Actions: ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentration of pollutants are expected and will result in poor air quality, especially in urban areas where pollutant emissions are higher. High levels of pollutants are expected to persist into this morning. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-02-15T17:23:32-00:00
